The Co3O4 catalysts with different precursors (Na2CO3, CH4N2O) were synthesized and evaluated for its o-xylene catalytic oxidation performance. A series of techniques including BET, XRD, TEM, XPS, H2-TPR were employed to characterize the physical and chemical properties of catalysts under various preparation conditions. The results indicated that physisorption played an important role in the o-xylene removal and higher calcination temperature destructed the specific surface areas of the Co3O4 samples. The enhanced catalytic performance of Co3O4 N catalyst was mainly attributed to be abundance in active Co3+ and lattice oxygen species, while that of Co3O4 C catalyst was ascribed to the formation of superoxide anion, especially the lower calcination temperature facilitated the generation of active species. In addition, the reaction mechanisms toward o-xylene oxidation over Co3O4 catalysts obtained by different preparation methods were explored in detail. The o-xylene molecule preferentially adsorbed onto the Co3+ ion sites, and was further oxidized by the lattice oxygen or superoxide anion with the product being o-methyl benzyl alcohol. Soon the benzyl alcohol was transformed into the o-methyl benzaldehyde, and afterward to form benzoic acid. Later, the benzoic acid was converted into small-molecule carboxylate for Co3O4 N catalyst, whereas for Co3O4 C catalysts, the benzoic acid was further turned into maleic acid subsequently into acetone. Finally, both the small-molecule carboxylate and acetone species were oxidized to CO2 and H2O. This finding offers some valuable insights for designing efficient o-xylene oxidation catalysts and mitigating industrial air pollution. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords O-xylene Co3O4 Preparation method Catalytic oxidation Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are a class of organic compounds with a boiling point of 50 ∼ 260 °C at atmospheric pressure and room temperature. These VOCs, especially BTX (benzene, toluene, and xylene), could not only induce a variety of diseases, and also participate in the formation of ozone and photochemical smog formation [1]. Among the three types of BTX substances, the degradation of o-xylene is more difficult because of the spatial site resistance of the bis-methyl group [2]. Therefore, there are urgent requirements to develop effective o-xylene treatment methods. Catalytic oxidation is considered the most economically effective method for treating VOCs due to its reduction of reaction activation energy and generation of non-toxic products—H2O and CO2 [3,4]. Transition metal oxides have gradually substituted noble metals owing to their high oxidizing capacity, low price, not prone to poisoning or sintered [1]. Cobalt oxide (Co3O4), a spinel-structure oxide with one Co2+ tetrahedron and two Co3+ octahedrons in coordination, are widely used in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs and shows high activity [1]. Bai et al. [5] had synthesized nano-Co3O4, 2D-Co3O4, and 3D-Co3O4 catalysts, respectively and found out that 3D-Co3O4 catalysts vis the hard template method performed the best catalytic activity for formaldehyde due to the clear channel structure, larger specific surface area, abundant active Co3+ ions as well as the active surface oxygen. Asimilar finding was reported by Wang et al., who studied ordered mesoporous Co3O4 supported palladium catalysts for the oxidation of o-xylene and pointed out that the good catalytic performance of Pd/porous Co3O4 was related to the particle size of palladium, the species of palladium oxide and the oxygen vacancy in Co3O4 [6]. Wang et al. [7] reported a facile solvent-free reaction process to prepare Co3O4-octahedrons, -plates, and -rods, and the Co3+ cations were verified as the active sites for CO oxidation. Gil-Barbarin et al. [8] structured Co3O4 catalysts with hollow nanotube morphology through the Kirkendall effect, which exhibited highly active for C2-chlorinated VOCs due to the formation of a large number of oxygen-vacancy defects. It is thereby an urgent demand, but it is still a momentous challenge to obtain a deeper fundamental understanding of catalytic oxidation mechanisms by establishing a correlation between the performance and the corresponding surface properties over Co3O4 catalyst. Based on the above-mentioned statement, this work focuses on the differences in the catalytic oxidation of o-xylene by Co3O4 catalysts obtained by two different homogeneous precipitation methods. O-xylene was selected as the target pollutant for catalytic oxidation performance evaluation. The relationship between the structure and performance, including critical role of morphology, specific surface area, reducing power, the valence state of Co, and the number of active oxygen species of Co3O4 in enhanced catalytic oxidation, was further revealed through a comparative study of Co3O4 catalysts prepared under various conditions via a series of designed experiments. Furthermore, the deeper mechanisms of the enhanced catalytic oxidation performance toward o-xylene over different Co3O4 catalysts were finally proposed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Co(NO3)2·6H2O reagents in this study were purchased from Macklin Corporation (Shanghai, China). 17.46 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 150 mL deionized water under stirring to form a clear solution at 50 °C. Subsequently, Na2CO3 solution (150 mL) was introduced into this solution, which was then stirred for an additional 3 h. After that, the mixture was filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. After naturally cooling down to room temperature (RT), the samples were calcined in static air at a heating ramp of 5 °C·min−1 from RT to 300 °C/400 °C/500 °C and maintained at the target temperature for 6 h. The obtained samples were coded as Co3O4 N-T, where T refers to the calcination temperature. 17.46 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 150 mL deionized water under stirring to form a clear solution at 80 °C. CH4N2O solution (150 mL, excessive precipitation) was added to the above solution. Then, the resulting solution was continuously stirred for 12 h. After that, the mixture was filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried at 100 °C for 12 h. After naturally cooling down to RT, the products were calcined in static air at a heating ramp of 5 °C min−1 from RT to 300 °C/400 °C/500 °C and maintained at the target temperature for 6 h. The obtained samples were named Co3O4 C-T, where T refers to the calcination temperature. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction(XRD) was used to identify the crystalline phase present in the catalysts. X-ray diffractometer (D8 Advance, Bruker, Germany) with monochromatic Cu Kα source operated at 40 kV and 40 mA was used in the diffraction angle range (10∼90°) at a scan rate of 6° min−1. A transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan) was used for obtaining the images for particle size. The catalysts' specific surface areas and pore volumes were measured using an N2 physical adsorption apparatus (QuadraSorb SI, Quantachrome, USA). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction(H2-TPR)was performed by automatic chemical adsorption instrument (BELCAT II, MicrotracBEL, Japan). During the operation of H2-TPR, 50 mg samples in a three-layer tubular reactor were heated to 300 °C at the rate of 10 °C min−1 in Ar (50 mL min−1) for 30 min, then sustained for 20 min after being cooled to RT with Ar (50 mL min−1). Then, the temperature was increased to 750 °C with 5 % H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) at 10 °C min−1. Consumption of H2 was recorded by the Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD) after the water was removed by a cooling trap. In-situ DRIFTS spectra of CO or o-xylene oxidation without O2 were measured on a Nicolet IS 50 spectrometer. Typically, a 50 mg sample without diluents was placed into the DRIFTS cell, flushed with N2 at 30 °C for 1 h and a reference spectrum was taken. During the CO or o-xylene adsorption, the sample was exposed to 1000 ppm CO or 100 ppm o-xylene gas flow for 0.5 h. Then the DRIFTS spectra were subsequently collected by accumulating 128 scans in the temperature range from 25 to 150 °C (CO) or 250 °C (o-xylene). 2.3 Evaluation of catalyst activity The catalytic oxidation performance of o-xylene was tested in a fixed-bed micro-reactor evaluation unit (i.d. = 4.0 mm), as shown in Fig. 1 . The sealed bubbling bottle containing the o-xylene immersed in the water bath at about 4 °C was employed to provide a constant o-xylene concentration. The feed gas is composed of the oxygen and nitrogen. gas chromatograph (GC7820, Agilent, USA) with a Carbo PLOT P7 column and two flame ionization detectors (FID) monitors the outlet o-xylene concentration. In each run, 100 mg of catalyst (40–60mesh) was filled into a microreactor with the reactant feed composed of 50 ppm o-xylene, 20.0 vol % O2 and N2 (balance) in terms of flow rate at 100 mL/min. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) is calculated to be 60,000 mL/(g·hr). To prevent anomalous temperature fluctuations, the thermal insulation device was opened before the commencement of the reaction, and the mixed gas was injected over eight hours. Then, the resistance furnace heated slowly from room temperature to the target temperature at 5 °C·min−1. The catalyst activity was evaluated by measuring the peak area of o-xylene in different reaction temperatures (from 120 to 280 °C). The conversion of o-xylene ( η o − xylene ) was calculated in Eqs. (1) : (1) η o − y x l e n e = C o − x y l e n e , i n − C o − x y l e n e , o u t C o − x y l e n e , i n × 100 Where, C o − xylene , in (ppm) and C o − xylene , out (ppm) are the concentrations of o-xylene in the inlet and outlet gas, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic oxidation of o-xylene Fig. 2 shows the catalytic performances of the Co3O4 catalysts toward o-xylene conversion as a function of reaction temperature with Na2CO3 and CH4N2O as precipitant, respectively. The 100 % o-xylene conversion(T100) was used to evaluate the catalytic performances. The catalytic performance for the oxidation of o-xylene over different catalysts follows the order: Na2CO3-300 °C>Na2CO3-400 °C>Na2CO3-500 °C, CH4N2O-300 °C>CH4N2O-400 °C>CH4N2O-500 °C. The Co3O4 C-300 °C catalyst exhibited the best activity, giving complete oxidation of 50 ppm o-xylene at 200 °C, whereas the T100 was 220 °C for Co3O4 N-300 °C catalyst. In addition, it was noteworthy that the water resistance of Co3O4 catalyst with CH4N2O as precipitant showed better water resisting property than that of Co3O4 with Na2CO3 as precipitant. 3.2 Morphology, crystalline phase and specific surface area To visualize the calcination temperature effect on Co3O4 catalysts, the Na2CO3 and CH4N2O as precipitant were investigated by TEM and HRTEM. As observed in Fig. 3 A´-F´ for the HRTEM images of catalysts of as-prepared Co3O4, the lattice fringe spacings are determined to be 0.244 nm, 0.286 nm, and 0.467 nm, corresponding to the (311), (220), and (111) planes of the Co3O4 crystals in the spinel phase, respectively [9]. Usually, the (111) crystal plane composed of Co2+ on nano-Co3O4 is believed not the active surface, while the (220) planes of the Co3O4 crystal is believed to be effective for the catalytic oxidation of CO, CH4 and VOCs [10]. That is probably because the (220) crystal planes are predominantly populated by abundant Co3+ species, and these exposed Co3+ ions on the (220) faces offer ample active sites for the oxidation reaction [10,11]. The reactant molecules diffuse in the pores and are activated by Co3+ in the (220) faces, consequently the amount of Co3+ in the (220) facet is critical for the oxidation performance [5]. Furthermore, >100 nanoparticles were measured for each sample and the results were statistically analysed. As illustrated in Table 1 , as the calcination temperature increased, the crystal size exhibited a gradual increase. This phenomenon could be attributed to the fact that as the calcination temperature rises, the nucleation rate rises as well, leading to an increase in particle aggregation and, consequently, an overall increase in the average particle size. Fig. 4 shows the XRD patterns of Co3O4 catalysts derived from different preparation methods. The characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.8°, 38.5°, 44.8°, 55.6°, 59.4°, and 65.2° are consistently observed across all the samples, which are assigned to the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511), and (440) planes of the Co3O4 spinel structure according to the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS No. 43–1003), and no peaks from other phase or impurity are detected. As depicted in Fig. 4, the intensities of the diffraction peaks become sharper and more pronounced with the calcination temperature increasing, especially evident in the peak at 31.3° This suggests that crystallite sizes and crystallinity improved as the calcination temperature rises, as inferred from the narrowing of the diffraction peaks as well. This result indicates that the smaller the particle size, the higher the catalytic activity, which is accordance with previous results [6]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the different Co3O4 catalysts are illuminated in Fig. 5 . Type-IV isotherms of the adsorption curves of the catalysts confirmed the existence of mesopores [1]. As shown in Fig. 5, the other all the Co3O4 catalysts belonged to the H3 Hysteresis Loops representative of the particle-piled pores [12]. The specific surface areas (SSAs) of the synthesized catalysts are listed in Table 1. As can be seen, the Co3O4–300 °C catalyst exhibited the highest SSA, and the SSAs decreased as the calcination temperature increased for a same precursor. Physisorption theory assumed that larger SSA was beneficial for the mass transfer and gas molecule adsorption over the catalyst surface [13]. The apparent inhibition in o-xylene catalytical oxidation performance with SSA decreasing in Fig. 2 suggested that physisorption participated in the reaction of o-xylene removal over the Co3O4 samples. 3.3 Chemical valence The O 1 s and Co 2p XPS spectra were measured to verify their chemical valence states. As shown in Fig. 6 a, c, the peak of O 1 s were resolved into three peaks, including lattice oxygen (Olatt), surface adsorbed oxygen Oads (O2−, O2 2−, O−), and -OH. The value of Oads/(Oads+Olatt) ratio usually was indicative of the adsorbed reactive oxygen concentration on the catalyst surface, as listed in Table 2 . It can be seen that the Oads/(Oads+Olatt) ratio of Co3O4-x follows the order: Co3O4-300 °C>Co3O4-400 °C>Co3O4-500 °C, suggesting that as the increase of calcination temperature, the amount of reactive oxygen species adsorbed on the catalyst surface decreases. The peaks located at 777.5 ∼ 778.0 eV and 780.05 ∼ 780.35 eV is associated with Co3+ 2p3/2 and Co2+2p3/2, respectively. The other spin orbits located at 794.35–794.45 eV, could be attributed to Co3+2p1/2 and Co2+2p1/2, respectively. Therefore, the XPS profile of Co species over different catalysts did not change significantly, implying that the chemical state of Co species was almost the same [6]. As seen from Table 2, the Co3+/(Co3++Co2+) ratio gradually declined with the rise of calcination temperature. It was reported that the ion Co3+ is generally recognized as active adsorption site, so low-temperature calcination can help improve the catalytic activity of the catalyst [14]. 3.4 Redox ability The reducibility of all the Co3O4 nanomaterials was characterized by H2-TPR. As shown in Fig. 7 , there were two distinct H2 consumption peaks (designated as I and II) ranging from 200 to 600 °C, attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO (Co3+→Co2+) and CoO to cobalt (Co2+→Co0), respectively [15,16]. Obvious, the H2 consumption peaks shifted to the higher temperature as the calcination temperature increased, indicating that calcination at low temperature (300 °C) favored the reduction of Co3O4, thus showing the best catalytic performance toward o-xylene. The reduction capability of the Co3O4 catalysts were further quantified by integrating the peak area of H2-TPR profiles and then normalizing it to the mass of the sample. As detailed in Table 3 , the adsorbed hydrogen amount per unit mass of the catalyst decreased as the calcination temperature increased, demonstrating that the catalysts calcined at 300 °C exhibited the best reducibility. This might be because the low temperature roasting process can maintain a high specific surface area of the Co3O4 catalyst and was therefore more conducive to the loading of the active component [9]. 3.5 In situ DRIFTS study The in situ DRIFTS tests were performed to investigate the catalytic mechanism of o-xylene oxidation over Co3O4 catalysts at different reaction temperatures. Firstly, CO oxidation without O2 as a probe reaction was used to analyze the carbonate types further to reveal the reaction sites of Co3O4 [17]. It can be observed from Fig. 8 a that a weak peak band located at 1036 cm−1 appeared initially after CO inlet, which should be attributed to the ν1 vibration of monodentate carbonate species [18]. In addition, the peak bands at 1303 cm−1, 1346 cm−1, 1464 cm−1, 1773 cm−1, and 1578 cm−1 grew in with time on stream, which could be attributed to the ν3 vibrational splitting of bidentate carbonate species [19]. The gradual growth of bidentate carbonate species suggested that CO oxidation over the Co3O4 catalysts with Na2CO3 as a precipitant mainly occurred at the surface lattice oxygen sites with bidentate carbonates as intermediates. Due to confirmed by XPS characterization results that more lattice oxygen existed in the Co3O4 N, the potential reaction pathways for CO oxidation over the Co3O4 N catalyst was proposed: ① The gaseous CO was adsorbed onto the catalysts’ surface to form the bidentate carbonates. ② As the reaction temperature increased, the bidentate carbonates extracted the surface lattice oxygen further to produce CO2 and oxygen cavities . Fig. 8c shows the DRIFTS spectra for CO oxidation ranging from 30 °C to 150 °C in the absence of O2 over the Co3O4 C catalysts. The peaks around 1036 cm−1 and 1082 cm−1 were assigned to the vibrations of the monodentate carbonate species, while the peaks at 1580 cm−1, 1438 cm−1, 1359 cm−1, 1264 cm−1, and 1170 cm−1 corresponded to the ν3 vibrational splitting of the bidentate carbonate species [18,20]. Thus, it could be presumed the carbonate species are formed by the reactive oxygen species interacted with adsorbed CO. Notably, two new peak bands located at 973 and 997 cm−1 appeared and were assigned to the OO vibration of superoxide, indicating that the surface of Co3O4 synthesized with CH4N2O as precipitant contained superoxide anion (-O2 −) [21]. Therefore, it could be inferred that the reaction of CO with superoxide anion over the Co3O4 C catalysts to generate CO2 and oxygen vacancies is the essence of the mechanism [14,22]. In brief, the oxidation of CO occurred via several pathways depending upon the different preparation methods for Co3O4 catalysts. The adsorption and oxidation reaction mechanisms of o-xylene on the Co3O4 catalysts were examined using in situ DRIFTS. As shown in Fig. 8b, the peaks associated with o-xylene adsorption gradually increased under the N2 atmosphere. The band located at 1035 cm−1 could be attributed to the lattice vibration of the cobalt-based spine [23], and the band at 1653 cm−1 to the backbone υ (C=C) vibration of the aryl ring [24]. The peak bands at 2800 and 2875 cm−1 could be assigned to the CH symmetric stretching vibrations of the -CH3 group, indicating the adsorption reaction toward o-xylene occurred on the Co3O4 N catalysts [1,25]. The adsorption band at 1097 cm−1 might be a characteristic peak of the alcohol salt species (-OH) [1]. This implies that the adsorbed o-xylene can interact with the catalyst to break the CH bond of methyl (-CH3) to produce benzyl alcohol. In addition, the benzaldehyde species (1533 and 1585 cm−1) and benzoic acid species (1462 and 1794 cm−1) were formed [26]. It was noted that new small-molecule carboxylate and anhydride peak bands located at 1265 cm−1 and 1735 cm−1 appeared when the temperature increased to 110 °C [24]. This indicated that the catalyst with CH4N2O as precipitant tended to degrade benzaldehyde and benzoic acid into small-molecule carboxylate species [27]. At the same time, the carbon dioxide bands around at 2336 and 2360 cm−1 were observed [28]. Based on the fact that the appearance of benzaldehyde and benzoic acid molecules and the depletion of hydroxyl species, the oxidation reaction mechanism of o-xylene with the lattice oxygen over the Co3O4 catalyst with Na2CO3 as precipitant might be as follows: o-xylene → o-methyl benzyl alcohol → o-methyl benzaldehyde (benzaldehyde) → benzoic acid →small-molecule carboxylate→ H2O and CO2. The in situ DRIFTS tests were performed to investigate the reaction mechanism of o-xylene adsorption and oxidation over Co3O4 C catalysts as well. As depicted in Fig. 8d, a small peak around 2937 cm−1 was observed, which was ascribed to the CH symmetric stretching vibration of -CH3 [1]. The appearance of new bands at 1034 and 1166 cm−1 were associated with the alcohol salt substances [26]. As temperature increased, the aldehyde group (-CHO) (1400 and 1430 cm−1) and carboxylate species (1765 cm−1) were formed [1,29], indicating that aldehyde species were further oxidized to carboxylate species. In addition, the benzoic acid species (1582 cm−1), maleic anhydride (1267 and 1474 cm−1) and ketone species (1660 cm−1) were observed [30,31], implying that all of them were critical intermediates in the oxidation of o-xylene. Furthermore, absorption bands designated as metal-OH or water molecules coordinated to the surface metal cations (3380 cm−1) and carbon dioxide (2338 and 2360 cm−1) were also observed [26]. Therefore, the oxidation reaction mechanism of o-xylene with the reactive superoxide anion over the Co3O4 catalyst with CH4N2O as precipitant might be as follows: o-xylene → o-methyl benzyl alcohol → o-methyl benzaldehyde (benzaldehyde) → benzoic acid → maleic acid → acetone → H2O and CO2. 3.6 Proposed reaction mechanism In this study, smaller grain size, larger specific surface area, higher valence state of Co and the content of lattice oxygen/active superoxide anion the over the Co3O4 catalysts were identified to be beneficial to increasing the catalysts’ efficiency toward o-xylene oxidation. Based on the above discussions, two distinct reaction pathways toward o-xylene oxidation processes were proposed over the two kinds of Co3O4 catalysts (Fig. 9 ). Firstly, the methyl group of the o-xylene was adsorbed onto the Co3+ ion, then the activated the o-xylene molecules on Co3+ cation site was further oxidized by the surface lattice oxygen or superoxide anion to form o-methyl benzyl alcohol, leading to active Co3+ sites that were partially reduced to Co2+ and neighboring oxygen vacancies being generated, and then the oxygen vacancies were replenished by the gaseous oxygen, resulting in the regeneration of active Co3+ sites. Later the benzyl alcohol was oxidized to o-methyl benzaldehyde, and afterward to generate benzoic acid. It was noteworthy that a significant accumulation of carboxylate species (benzoic acid) occurred over the two kinds of Co3O4 catalysts, suggesting that further degradation of the carboxylate species became a rate-determining step. The later reaction product varied in the type of catalyst. For Co3O4 N catalyst, the benzoic acid was further degraded into small-molecule carboxylate, while for Co3O4 C catalysts, it was further degraded into maleic acid subsequently into acetone. However, the final products were the same, both were CO2 and H2O. 4 Conclusions The Co3O4 catalysts with pure phase and characteristic spinel structure were successfully prepared by using two different homogeneous precipitation methods, respectively, and a series of characterization techniques and bench-scale experiments were performed to gain insights into the essence for o-xylene oxidation over the Co3O4 N and Co3O4 C catalysts. The main conclusions from this experimental study are summarized as follows: (1) As the calcination temperature increased, the particle tended to sinter, resulting in the SSA of the catalysts gradually decreased. The positive correlation between o-xylene catalytical oxidation efficiency and SSA indicated that physisorption contributed to the o-xylene removal efficiency over the Co3O4 samples. (2) The Co3O4 N catalyst was more abundant in Co3+ and Oads active species, while that of Co3O4 C catalyst was rich in the active superoxide anion. Among the different kinds of catalysts, Co3O4 C-300 °C catalyst exhibited the best activity toward o-xylene oxidation. In addition, it was found that lower calcination temperature was beneficial to the formation of surface lattice oxygen as well as the active superoxide anion than that of higher temperature. (3) The oxidation mechanism of o-xylene over Co3O4 catalysts obtained by different preparation methods were revealed in detail: The characterization results indicated that o-xylene molecule preferentially adsorbed on Co3+ cation sites, then it was further oxidized by the surface lattice oxygen or superoxide anion to form o-methyl benzyl alcohol. Subsequently the benzyl alcohol was oxidized to o-methyl benzaldehyde, and afterward to generate benzoic acid. For Co3O4 N catalyst, the benzoic acid converted into small-molecule carboxylate, while for Co3O4 C catalysts, it was further converted into maleic acid subsequently into acetone. Finally, both small-molecule carboxylate and acetone products converted to CO2 and H2O. coredata.dc:description: The Co3O4 catalysts with different precursors (Na2CO3, CH4N2O) were synthesized and evaluated for its o-xylene catalytic oxidation performance. A series of techniques including BET, XRD, TEM, XPS, H2-TPR were employed to characterize the physical and chemical properties of catalysts under various preparation conditions. The results indicated that physisorption played an important role in the o-xylene removal and higher calcination temperature destructed the specific surface areas of the Co3O4 samples. The enhanced catalytic performance of Co3O4 N catalyst was mainly attributed to be abundance in active Co3+ and lattice oxygen species, while that of Co3O4 C catalyst was ascribed to the formation of superoxide anion, especially the lower calcination temperature facilitated the generation of active species. In addition, the reaction mechanisms toward o-xylene oxidation over Co3O4 catalysts obtained by different preparation methods were explored in detail. The o-xylene molecule preferentially adsorbed onto the Co3+ ion sites, and was further oxidized by the lattice oxygen or superoxide anion with the product being o-methyl benzyl alcohol. Soon the benzyl alcohol was transformed into the o-methyl benzaldehyde, and afterward to form benzoic acid. Later, the benzoic acid was converted into small-molecule carboxylate for Co3O4 N catalyst, whereas for Co3O4 C catalysts, the benzoic acid was further turned into maleic acid subsequently into acetone. Finally, both the small-molecule carboxylate and acetone species were oxidized to CO2 and H2O. This finding offers some valuable insights for designing efficient o-xylene oxidation catalysts and mitigating industrial air pollution.

coredata.dc:title: Effects of the preparation methods of Co3O4 catalysts on catalytic oxidization performance toward o-xylene
